awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Slip-Clutch of Biological Machines: The Kinetochore-Microtubule Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Living cells and tissues have the ability to generate directed forces and to remodel themselves.  Both abilities are at the core of what defines life. How can a cell maintain its mechanical integrity while being dynamic, flexible and remodeling itself in space and time? We now know a lot about the mechanics of individual molecules.  Our understanding of how molecules work together to create force in a cell is much weaker. Biological systems are dynamic, sculpting themselves into new shapes by internal forces to accommodate their roles in a human or animal body; description of such structures defies current traditional mechanical frameworks. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project focuses on the mechanics of the kinetochore--the macromolecular machine that segregates chromosomes at cell division.  Errors in its function can lead to disease (such as cancer) and birth defects.  The project will develop new methods to measure the 'slip-clutch' forces that permit the molecules to slide and to generate forces at the correct times in order to properly separate the new daughter cells during cell division.

The aim of this CAREER award is to develop and use state-of-the-art tools to control mechanical force inside cells and probe how force regulates the slip-clutch of biological interfaces with the cytoskeleton - the cell's roadways and pillars. We focus on the slip-clutch interface that moves chromosomes at cell division, that of the kinetochore linking chromosomes to dynamic spindle microtubule tips. The kinetochore-microtubule interface resides deep inside cells, and thus tugging on it to probe its mechanics is particularly challenging. To probe its slip-clutch, we will use a novel and unique combination of tools: we will use laser ablation to control forces and probe material properties and grip strength (clutch), protein photomarking to probe dynamics (slip), and molecular tools to probe mechanisms regulating the interface's slip and clutch behaviors. Together, these will enable us to test the hypothesis that independent force-based mechanisms regulate the slip and the clutch.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Mechanical force organizes life at all scales.  While we know much about the mechanics individual molecules, our understanding of how they give rise to those of larger scale biological structures is still poor. In large part, this is because unlike the engineered macroscopic structures that we commonly build, biological structures are dynamic. For example, cell-to-cell, cell-to-substrate and chromosome-to-microtubule interfaces must all provide a persistent attachment and yet be able to slide and reorganize; moreover, their mechanics and dynamics must integrate to coordinate distant events.  How are these interfaces’ “slip-clutch” behavior engineered to support these functions? 

The aim of this CAREER project was to develop and use tools to control mechanical force inside cells and probe how it regulates the slip-clutch of biological interfaces with the cytoskeleton – the cell’s roadways and pillars.  We focused on the slip-clutch interface that moves chromosomes at cell division, that of the kinetochore linking chromosomes to dynamic spindle microtubule tips. We developed two approaches to pull on chromosomes inside cells to probe how they are attached to microtubule roadways: one uses a laser to trigger the recruitment of the cell’s motors to pull chromosomes along these roadways, and the other uses a microneedle to go inside the cell and directly pull on chromosomes attached to their roadways. We expect that these approaches will be broadly useful for probing the mechanics of the machines that pull on chromosomes and segregate them. Further, our worked revealed how the chromosome-to-microtubule interface can dissipate force to preserve this essential connection point, and the role of different molecules in controlling how much “slip” and “grip” there is at this interface. Indeed, having a balance of both “slip” and “grip” is essential for chromosomes to correctly segregate and thus for our genome to be preserved when cells divide.

Broader Impacts: We aimed to make live microscopy of local biological specimens accessible to a broad and diverse set of the general population and K-12 students, with a focus on the visualization of striking force-generating dynamic processes. While our in-person interactions with the general population and K-12 students were limited due to the Covid-19 pandemic, we began developing simple protocols to prepare “everyday life” invertebrate specimens for live imaging with a Foldscope, an optical microscope costing 1$ to build out of paper origami and a small lens. After these protocols are more broadly tested and refined, anyone with a Foldscope will ultimately be empowered to directly visualize processes such as cell motility, cell division and tissue development, and a cell phone camera will allow time-lapse imaging if desired. The main premise is that direct “experience” of the beauty of living forms is critical in igniting passion for science, and will drive people to ask (and perhaps answer) their own questions about the natural world. To aid in the development of these protocols and engage the general population and K-12 students with cells and their mechanics, we visited a middle school and high school, organized a booth at the Bay Area Science Festival (before and during the pandemic, both in person and online), developed a display box at the San Francisco Exploratorium – all focusing on single cells and their force-generating processes. These events allowed the general population and K-12 students to directly experience dynamic micro-scale processes in biology with their own eyes, and for us to get feedback on how to improve Foldscope-based protocols to make these processes accessible to more people.
